title: 108_hr3563
content: The "Cargo Theft Prevention Act" may be cited as the short title. This act includes provisions for the collection of cargo theft data. The Attorney General must issue regulations within 18 months of the Act's enactment to allow for reporting of cargo theft offenses, create a database for these reports, and prescribe access procedures. The Attorney General must issue regulations for reporting cargo theft, create a database, and prescribe access procedures for Federal, State, and local agencies to assist in investigating and prosecuting cargo theft perpetrators. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant agencies, establishes an outreach program to harmonize cargo theft data reporting among State and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General establishes an outreach program to harmonize cargo theft data reporting among State and local law enforcement officials. The program aims to disseminate cargo theft information to appropriate law enforcement officials and submit an annual report on its implementation to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2003 through 2007 to carry out the requirements, with limitations on the disclosure of reports and data. Cargo theft data reporting created under section 1(a)(2) is exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. SEC. 3. THEFT OF INTERSTATE OR FOREIGN SHIPMENTS OR VESSELS. The amendment to Section 659 of title 18, United States Code includes adding new categories like "trailer," "air cargo container," and expanding the definition of theft to include various locations like intermodal containers and warehouses. The amendment also increases the penalty from one year to three years for theft of interstate or foreign shipments. The amendment to Section 659 of title 18, United States Code expands the definition of theft to include various categories like "trailer" and "air cargo container." It also increases the penalty for theft of interstate or foreign shipments from one year to three years. Additionally, amendments to Sections 2311, 2312, and 2313 define "vessel" and include transportation and sale of stolen vessels in the law. The United States Sentencing Commission will review sentencing guidelines for offenses under sections 659 or 2311 of title 18, United States Code. The Attorney General must submit an annual report on law enforcement activities related to cargo theft investigations and prosecutions. The Attorney General will ensure that cargo theft reports are included as a separate category in the Uniform Crime Reporting System by December 31, 2005.
